    Introduction to RUGtools

    Justin M. Shea

    April 23, 2018

    Introduction-RUGtools.Rmd

    Introduction

    R User Group Introduction Slides template

    This is a traditional ioslides R Markdown template, but modified to contain default content routinely used when introducing Chicago R user group meetups. Slides are useful because they look good and you won’t forget to do important things like thanking the sponsors! Slides can be accessed from within R Studio using the New R Markdown dialog menu, and then selecting From Template. One can also use the draft function, exemplified below.

    rmarkdown::draft(file="new_meetup.Rmd", template = "intro_slides", package="RUGtools")

    Estimate your pizza order

    In Chicago, we think a lot about Pizza. And if one is involved in the local meetup culture, this is doubly so. At a recent meetup group (which ironically shared the same name as a pizza shape), I counted nearly 6 large pizzas left over. Struck by an overwhelming sorrow, I vowed that we shall never be part of such a tragedy. With a few data points, the pizza_estimate function helps ensure we are able to look ourselves in the mirror the next morning.

    pizzas <- pizza_estimate(registered = 140, pizza_diameter = 18, attend_rate = 0.60, 
               serving = 2, style = "thin")

kable(pizzas)
    registered est_attend eaters_per_pizza style pizza_estimate
    140 84 5.342811 thin 16

    Channeling our ever-curious pizza scientist, it turns out the Chicago “party cut” (thin-crust cut into small squares) inherits a few very attractive properties when dividing multiple pizzas among n guests. Smaller pieces allow guests to more precisely estimate pizza consumption, thus decreasing the integer-programming problem exacerbated by larger slices. By requesting the “party cut”, one reduces wasted pizza and exhibits great stewardship of the sponsor resources bestowed upon them.

    Data and Analysis

    Chicago R User Group data is included and downloaded from meetup.com/ChicagoRUG. Personally identifiable information has been removed, data formatted and ready for analysis.

    How many members joined since January of 2017?

    Load the member list data.

    data(member_list)

    How many members do we have?

    NROW(member_list$Member.ID)
    ## [1] 3101

    Lets plot it!

    plot(y = member_list$Member.ID, x = member_list$Joined.Group.on, type = "l", col = "blue",
     main = "Cumulative CRUG members",  
         ylab = "Members", xlab = "")

    How many joined since January 2017?

    members_2017_present <- subset(member_list, Joined.Group.on > "2017-01-01")

max(members_2017_present$Member.ID) - min(members_2017_present$Member.ID)
    ## [1] 964

    How many joined between meetups?

    First, get a unique ordered list of Meetup dates

    Meetup_dates <- sort(unique(member_list$Last.Attended))

new_members <- subset(member_list, Joined.Group.on > Meetup_dates[NROW(Meetup_dates)])

    Then count the number of new members joined between the most recent meetup and the one prior to that.

    new_members2 <- subset(member_list, Joined.Group.on <= Meetup_dates[NROW(Meetup_dates)] &
                                    Joined.Group.on > Meetup_dates[NROW(Meetup_dates)-1])

NROW(new_members2)
    ## [1] 84

    In danger of repeating the above analysis several times over, we created a function new_mem_counter to count the number of new members joined between meetups for all meetups in the data set.

    new_members <- new_mem_counter(member_list)

kable(new_members, align = 'l')

    Lets Explore the new_members data set. Which gap between meetups had the most new members?

    max_new_members <- new_members[new_members$New==max(new_members$New),]

kable(max_new_members, align = 'l')
    Date New
    37 2016-06-05 161

    Plot the new members data.

       # Create Date Range Index
  Start_Date <- "2010-01-01"
    End_Date <- Sys.Date()
  Date_Index <- as.numeric(row.names(new_members[new_members$Date > Start_Date &
                                                new_members$Date <= End_Date,]))
  
  # Create x-axis labels, using year-month date format
  x_labels <- format(new_members$Date[Date_Index], "%Y-%m")

  # Plot
  barplot(new_members$New[Date_Index], names.arg = x_labels,
         main = "CRUG members, joined between meetups",  
         ylab = "New Members", xlab = "")

    Plot the new members data since 2017.

       # Create Date Range Index
  Start_Date <- "2017-01-01"
    End_Date <- Sys.Date()
  Date_Index <- as.numeric(row.names(new_members[new_members$Date > Start_Date &
                                                new_members$Date <= End_Date,]))
  
  # Create x-axis labels, using year-month date format
  x_labels <- format(new_members$Date[Date_Index], "%Y-%m")

  # Plot
  barplot(new_members$New[Date_Index], names.arg = x_labels, las=2,
         main = "CRUG members, joined between meetups",  
         ylab = "New Members", xlab = "")
